comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content:
A lengthy article entitled 'The Butter Trade in Cork' in The Daily News, April 22nd 1851, concludes:
Some attempts were also made, but without success, to remove the market to the flat of the city, the approaches to it being rather steep and difficult, particularly in frosty weather. But these approaches have all been remedied, pricipally at the expense of the merchants, as well as a new one (Mulgrave-road) constructed at a very large cost. Within the present year a sum of 4,000l. is being expended in enlarging and beautifying the market; a commercial room, reading room, committee and other offices, being added to it, as well as a beautiful pillared entance erected in front of Mulgrave-road.
And from a lengthy statement from the Cork Committee of merchants respecting the Cork butter market, concerning the operation of the market, published in Freeman's Nov 29th 1852
The committee provide four inspectors, or tasters of butter, men of general intelligence, unexceptionable character, and matured knowledge of this article and its distinctive qualities, whose whole time is required to be devoted to the business of the committee, to the exclusion of any other pusuit or employment whatever. These officers receive a salary of 150l. per annum.
I quite fancy the job of butter inspector, but before I apply, do I have to provide my own toast and marmite to go with it? And can I take it to the reading room with a cup of tea and a good book to consider my findings?

comment._content: "The Cork Butter Market - a visit to the butter exchange" from Freeman's, Jan 8th 1856. This describes in intricate detail how the butter prices were determined. As reported in the Preston Guardian in November 1856. Price is per firkin, and the different categories("Firsts" etc) refer to the quality as determined by the inspectors (I assume).
